metadata.title: Piper Aerostar
aws::graph::propositions: Merion Mid-Air Collision of 1991
Piper PA-60-601 is a type of Piper Aerostar aircraft.
Piper PA-60-601 with registration N3645D was involved in a mid-air collision.
Bell 412SP helicopter with registration N78S was involved in a mid-air collision.
The mid-air collision occurred on April 4, 1991.
The mid-air collision occurred over Lower Merion Township, Pennsylvania.
The collision occurred during a visual inspection of the Piper's nose landing gear.
The collision killed all four pilots in both aircraft.
John Heinz was a passenger in the Piper PA-60-601.
John Heinz was the United States Senator for Pennsylvania.
John Heinz was the sole passenger in the Piper PA-60-601.
John Heinz was killed in the collision.
Wreckage from the collision fell on an elementary school.
Wreckage from the collision fell on nearby houses.
The collision resulted in the deaths of two schoolchildren.
The collision severely burned a third schoolchild.
The collision caused minor injuries to four other bystanders.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) attributed the accident to poor judgment by the pilots of both aircraft.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) attributed the accident to poor decision-making by the pilots of both aircraft.
A contributing factor to the accident was a lack of direction in the PA-60 flight manual.
The PA-60 flight manual lacked procedures regarding what to do if the cockpit indicator light did not show that the nosegear was down and locked.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) stated that landing with improperly deployed gear would have been safer than the improvised aerial inspection.

text: On April 4, 1991, in the Merion mid-air collision, Piper PA-60-601 N3645D collided with a Bell 412SP helicopter, N78S, over  Lower Merion Township, Pennsylvania, during a visual inspection of the Piper's nose landing gear. The collision killed all four pilots in both aircraft along with John Heinz, United States Senator for Pennsylvania, who was the sole passenger in the Piper. Wreckage fell on an elementary school and nearby houses, killing two schoolchildren, severely burning a third, and causing minor injuries to four other bystanders. The NTSB attributed the accident to poor judgment and decision-making by the pilots of both aircraft. A contributing factor was a lack of direction in the PA-60 flight manual regarding procedures if the cockpit indicator light did not show that the nosegear was down and locked; landing with improperly deployed gear would have been safer than the improvised aerial inspection, the NTSB said.
